- Title: Python Programming                 Code: CNTT1180E
- Credits: 3 (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
- Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
- Lecture: 35 hrs
- Exercises on class: 10 hrs
- Self-study: 90 hrs.
- Parallel course(s): None

- MSc. Cao Thị Thu Hương,Tel: 0912916316 Email: huongct@neu.edu.vn

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental □ | Fundamental □
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective □
* Meeting hour:

This course introduces the programming environment, architecture overview and application capabilities of Python.
- This course consists of the basics of programming with Python such as variables, data types, control structures, program design with functions and modules with Python programming language.
- This course also consists of methods of data analysis and data visualization with popular Python libraries such as Pandas, NumPy, Matplotlib.

Textbook(s):
[1] John Hunt, A Beginners Guide to Python 3 Programming, Springer, 2019.
[2]. John Hunt, Advanced Guide to Python 3 Programming, Springer, 2019.
[3]. Fabio Nelli, Python Data Analytics - Data Analysis and Science Using Pandas, matplotlib, and the Python Programming Language, Apress Media, 2015.
Others:
[4] Jake VanderPlas, Python Data Science Handbook, O’Reilly Media, 2017.
Software: Visual Studio Code, PyCharm

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goals Description | PLOs | Proficiency scale
G1 | The course provides in-depth knowledge of the Python programming language: data types, control structures, object-oriented programming; program design with functions and modules; work with Python data visualization and analysis libraries such as NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib. | PLO1.3 PLO1.4 PLO1.5 | 4
G2 | Learning to practice thinking skills, problem solving and good practice skills with the Python programming language | PLO2.2 | 4
G3 | The course contributes to the development of the ability to work independently or in a team, to properly understand the responsibility of job performance and professional ethics. | PLO3.1 PLO3.4 | 4, 4, 4

G1 | CLO1.2 | Perform data analysis and data visualization operations with Python. Works with popular Python libraries such as NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib. | ITU4
G2 | CLO2.1 | The students have skilled in searching, synthesizing, analyzing, and using libraries in Python for data analysis and processing. | TU4
G3 | CLO3.1 | Ability to self-study Python-related materials to complete assigned assignments. | U4
G3 | CLO3.2 | Consciously organize class discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for the exercises assigned by the lecturer. | U4
G3 | CLO3.3 | Proper understanding of responsibility in job performance, professional ethics in work related to Python programming. | U4

chunks.text:
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In the case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments. These points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
chunks.breadcrumbs: 9. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION > 9.2. Requirements for attending classes.

chunks.text:
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

9. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION
9.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams.
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
9.2. Requirements for attending classes.
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In the case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments. These points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
9.3. Requirements for in-class behavior
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
